diaphragmatic surface of the spleen, which lies at the level of ribs 9, 10 and 11. Identify its sharp borders and its visceral surface. You have already observed the four organs adjacent to the visceral surface of the spleen: the stomach, the pancreas, the left kidney and the transverse colon at its left colic flexure. 
The spleen, as you know from your understanding of the immune system, processes blood for antigen and for spent formed elements. The spleen is wholly intraperitoneal, except at its hilus.
to the right and grasp the spleen with your right hand. Pull the spleen anteriorly in order to identify its features. Note the smooth
Thus, the spleen’s relationship to ribs 9, 10, and 11 of clinical importance in rib fractures and thoracentesis. A variety of infections and disease processes might cause an enlarged spleen
USING your left hand, retract the fundus of the stomach

Because of its large blood volume, the spleen, if lacerated, bleeds profusely into the peritoneal cavity, as may occur as a result of a rib fracture or a penetrating wound. Also, it is important to remember that the spleen may be punctured accidentally during a pleural tap (thoracentesis).
(splenomegaly).  If, during physical examination, the spleen can be palpated inferior to the costal margin, it is considered to be enlarged.
That's right! The spleen is located in the upper left quadrant. The splenic artery is seen extending to it from the celiac trunk.
